scenarioDescription:
The HD 21693 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 21693 is a star with 0.8 times the mass of the Sun, and NaN times its radius. It is located 108.46 light years away from the solar system.

HD 21693 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 21693 system


HD 21693 b

HD 21693 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2019-02, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 21693 b is 8.236 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 21693 b is 2.800 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 21693 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HD 21693 c

HD 21693 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2019-02, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.26 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 21693 c is 17.395 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 21693 c is 4.340 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 21693 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system HD 21693, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: HD 21693 - System With 2 Exoplanets
